title: Welcome to my website!
text:
Welcome to my website!
Curriculum Vitae | Job Market Paper | Research | Teaching

Welcome! I am a Ph.D.¬†candidate in the Department of Economics at Georgia State University on the 2025-2026 job market. I am an applied microeconomist with research interests in Health, Public, Labor, and Development Economics. My research examines how access to healthcare infrastructure affects population health, with a focus on access to mental health treatment facilities (JMP), emergency medical services, and maternal healthcare. I combine cutting-edge causal inference methods with novel data from the United States and Nigeria to provide the first causal evidence on these critical policy questions.
I am also a research assistant at the Center on Health and Homelessness in the School of Public Health at Georgia State University, working on the Program and Process Evaluation‚Äôs Evidence Gap Map Project. Previously, I was a Research Assistant at the Centre for Econometric and Allied Research (CEAR) at the University of Ibadan, where I developed expertise in development economics and healthcare systems in Sub-Saharan Africa. Here is my CV, and you can reach out to me at oyusuff4@student.gsu.edu.

Recent Highlights:

Recipient of the Center for the Economic Analysis of Risk (CEAR): Dissertation Fellowship & CEAR Scholar, Robinson College of Business, GSU (2025-2026)
Selected for the Institute for Research on Poverty (IRP) Professional Development Training, University of Wisconsin-Madison (2025-2026)
Recipient of Association for Public Policy & Management Equity & Inclusion Fellowship (2025)
Recipient of the Association for Mentoring & Inclusion in Economics Fellowship (2025)
Listed on the AEA CSMGEP Minority Job Market Candidates 2025-26

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.

title: Research
text:
Mental Healthcare Facilities and Mortality: Evidence from Local Access and Insurance Expansion


Abstract (click to expand)


Do mental health treatment facilities save lives? Using County Business Patterns data (1999-2016) and within-county variation, I provide the first causal evidence that mental health infrastructure reduces mortality broadly. Each additional facility prevents 1.56 deaths per 100,000 residents from all causes annually, with mental and behavioral disorder (MBD) mortality declining by 0.079%. A 10% increase in facilities lowers overall mortality by 0.5% and MBD mortality by 2%. Three key findings emerge: (1) facility closures increase mortality ten times more than openings reduce it, revealing asymmetries with welfare implications; (2) Medicaid expansion amplifies facility effectiveness by 26% in high-uninsurance counties, demonstrating that insurance and infrastructure are complements, not substitutes; (3) facilities operate through multiple mechanisms beyond direct treatment, serving as gateways to disability programs and enabling pharmaceutical access. Effects concentrate among elderly and less-educated populations who face the highest access barriers. Event studies using the Sun and Abraham (2021) estimator show immediate, persistent effects with no pre-trends. The benefit-cost ratio exceeds 4-to-1, with each facility generating $11.7 million in annual net benefits. Results indicate that neither insurance expansion nor infrastructure investment alone maximizes health benefits; coordinated policies addressing both dimensions are essential for reducing mortality.

title: Research
text:
Mental Healthcare Facilities and Mortality: Evidence from Local Access and Insurance Expansion


Abstract (click to expand)


Do mental health treatment facilities save lives? Using County Business Patterns data (1999-2016) and within-county variation, I provide the first causal evidence that mental health infrastructure reduces mortality broadly. Each additional facility prevents 1.56 deaths per 100,000 residents from all causes annually, with mental and behavioral disorder (MBD) mortality declining by 0.079%. A 10% increase in facilities lowers overall mortality by 0.5% and MBD mortality by 2%. Three key findings emerge: (1) facility closures increase mortality ten times more than openings reduce it, revealing asymmetries with welfare implications; (2) Medicaid expansion amplifies facility effectiveness by 26% in high-uninsurance counties, demonstrating that insurance and infrastructure are complements, not substitutes; (3) facilities operate through multiple mechanisms beyond direct treatment, serving as gateways to disability programs and enabling pharmaceutical access. Effects concentrate among elderly and less-educated populations who face the highest access barriers. Event studies using the Sun and Abraham (2021) estimator show immediate, persistent effects with no pre-trends. The benefit-cost ratio exceeds 4-to-1, with each facility generating $11.7 million in annual net benefits. Results indicate that neither insurance expansion nor infrastructure investment alone maximizes health benefits; coordinated policies addressing both dimensions are essential for reducing mortality.

title: Projects
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth‚Äôs history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Teaching
text:
ECON 4350: Economics of Poverty and Public Policy
Fall 2024 | Enrollment: 44 students (75% first-generation college students)

Teaching Evaluation Summary | Syllabus | Teaching Statement


More on teaching evaluation summary


Teaching Excellence
Overall Rating: 4.6/5.0
Student Achievement of Learning Objectives: 4.8/5.0
Course increased ability to critically evaluate ideas: 4.8/5.0
Created an environment that helped students learn: 4.6/5.0
Course challenged students to think: 4.7/5.0
Student Feedback:

‚ÄúProfessor Yusuff put tremendous effort into finding material that enhanced our learning. He always looked to our preferences and made sure that we were heard.‚Äù


‚ÄúVery knowledgeable in his field, lectures and explanations were clear. He was always open to questions and you could tell that he really wanted to make sure we understood the material.‚Äù


‚ÄúI truly appreciated how he encouraged us to participate in discussions; he was always eager to hear our ideas and would challenge them further, helping us become more informed.‚Äù

Course Innovations: - Integrated hands-on data analysis using R and American Community Survey data

Connected theories to Atlanta neighborhoods (MARTA transit gaps, Atlanta Medical Center closure)
Implemented peer tutoring system with extra credit incentives
Provided flexible office hours (virtual and in-person) for working students

Impact Beyond the Classroom: - Two students gained admission to economics graduate programs with my recommendation letters

Mentored first-year PhD students preparing for comprehensive exams
Students applied course concepts to analyze poverty in their home communities



ECON 4210: Health Economics
Spring 2026

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching Interests

Micro/Macro Economics, Health Economics, Public Economics, Urban Economics, Development Economics, Applied Econometrics, Causal Inference, Statistics, Mathematics for Economics, Applied Economic Analysis for Policy. Contact: oyusuff4@student.gsu.edu



More about my teaching approach


I specialize in making complex economic concepts accessible to diverse student populations, particularly first-generation and working students. My experience spans core courses (Principles through Advanced Microeconomics) and specialized fields aligned with my research (Health, Public, and Urban Economics). I am developing innovative courses including ‚ÄúEconomics of Health Disparities‚Äù and ‚ÄúApplied Economic Analysis for Policy‚Äù that bridge rigorous methods with real-world applications. Having taught 75% first-generation students with a 4.6/5.0 rating, I excel at maintaining high standards while providing multiple pathways to success.

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching Philosophy


More about my teaching philosophy


As a first-generation college student, I understand the transformative power of accessible and engaging education. My teaching approach centers on three principles: accessibility through relevance, active engagement through collaboration, and empowerment through mentorship. I connect economic concepts to students‚Äô lived experiences, making abstract theories tangible through local examples and real-world applications. Having taught primarily first-generation and working students at Georgia State University, I‚Äôve learned that students excel when they see themselves reflected in the material and when multiple pathways to success are provided.

title: Teaching
text:
Invited Workshops & Training

Facilitator: Introduction to Causal Inference and Applied Microeconometrics
Workshop for African Researchers and Students | Virtual | May 24, 2025
Organized by Omolola Akinde-Fasasi

Lecture Slides | Workshop Recap


Workshop details


Designed and delivered comprehensive workshop on modern causal inference methods for 35+ researchers and students across Africa. Covered difference-in-differences estimation, instrumental variables approaches, and regression discontinuity designs with practical applications to development economics and policy evaluation. Workshop materials have been requested by researchers across multiple African countries and are now publicly available to support quantitative research capacity building in the Global South.
